results.title: Energy. Ep. 2. The Nuclear alternative
results.creator_credit: George McQuilkin, Anthony Morris, Jane Treiman and Churchill Films
results.brief_description: Explores fission power, how it works and the controversies over safety and radioactive waste. Stresses societies’ need to develop ways of using less energy. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: Enjoying Australasian wine
results.brief_description: The wine industries of Australia and New Zealand are producing wines of world class quality. To discover just how we are achieving this phenomenal success, we visit major wine growing areas in the two countries to hear from the growers and winemakers, followed by wine-tasting segments with Michael Hill-Smith, Australia’s only “Master of wine”. The areas visited are: the Hunter Valley and Mudgee, North-eastern Victoria, South Australia, Western Australia and New Zealand. Introduced by Len Evans.

results.title: English without tears
results.creator_credit: Harold French, Sydney Box, William Sassoon, Anatole de Grunwald and Two Cities Films
results.brief_description: Set in Geneva Switzerland during World War II “English without tears” is a gentle and entertaining romantic satire. The multi-plots within the film mainly focus on the small things that matter to people during wartime. An aristocratic family including an eccentric bird fancier (Margaret Rutherford) leaves for Geneva. The faithful butler joins the army and becomes lieutenant. The charming daughters falls for the butler who is successful in his new role. The plot becomes amusing as the story unfolds while the class barriers of peacetime relax and the romantic complications reveal themselves. A charming English studio film. Cast includes Michael Wilding, Margaret Rutherford, Lili Palmer and Penelope Ward.

results.title: Energy highway
results.creator_credit: Dennis Hill Productions, Peter Johnson and Film Australia
results.brief_description: This film shows the construction of a natural gas pipeline stretching half way across Australia. Made for the Pipeline Authority, this film shows the immensity of the task and the people involved in achieving this feat

results.title: English at Work. - Eps. 7-9.
results.creator_credit: Karl McPhee, Ray Quint, Diane Sundin and SBS-TV
results.brief_description: Episode 7, “Paying tax”, follows a group of employed and unemployed young people to illustrate how the Australian taxation system works. In “Working together” workers and employers at a car factory find that co- operation and dialogue can go a long way in removing problems between staff and management. In episode 9, “Reading and writing”, we discover that problems in effective communication and literacy are common and often the reason for poor work performance.

results.title: Energy and matter
results.creator_credit: Robert Verrall, Joseph Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A look at energy and what it is, designed to encourage understanding and experimentation among even the youngest of budding physicists. This film pictures energy in familiar forms - light, heat, motion, etc. - and shows its origin in the sun. The illustration is cartoon-style, with color and movement appealing to youthful imaginations.

results.title: English at Work. - Eps. 4-6.
results.creator_credit: Karl McPhee, Mark Sanders, Diane Sundin and SBS-TV
results.brief_description: Episode four, “Being in a union”, is about the various functions performed by trade unions. In “Using public transport” a man used to driving everywhere finds that public transport can turn out to be much more convenient: but only once you can understand timetables and how to access information. And in “Using a phone” information is given on some of the barriers that inhibit people from using a phone effectively.

results.title: Energy
results.brief_description: Shows the mining of coal, its conversion into electrical energy, and the problems enocuntered in this conversion such as the disposal of waste products. Also looks at atomic power stations and their inherent problems. The concept of tidal power as an alternative source is mentioned. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: English at work. - Eps. 34-36.
results.creator_credit: Michael Karris, Richard Jasek, Diane Sundin and SBS-TV
results.brief_description: The final three episodes of the “English at work” series. In “Helping with problems” we are shown the various ways people can assist others by being good listeners and being prepared to stand up for the rights of others. In “Saving energy” we are shown ways to be more energy efficient at both work and home. “Preventing sexual harassment”. The prevention of sexual harassment and intimidation is shown to be the responsibility of management, workers, and unions: in fact every woman and man needs to object to the practice of harassment in their workplace whenever it occurs.

results.title: End of a summers day
results.creator_credit: Robert Fortier, Don Rennick, George Pearson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A comment without words on the ancient theme of love and war: the man called to arms for his country; his sweetheart left behind to mourn; sorrow and separation visited upon the innocent. This is how it has always been, but implicit in the film are the protests of a new generation: Must it always be so? Is not love better than war? Cast includes: Michel Gauthier, Dennis Nadeau, Caroline Price, Paul Sullivan. (Award: New York)
